title: EU, US in 'intense negotiations' over data transfer deal

text:
EU, US in 'intense negotiations' over data transfer deal
The EU said Friday it was in "intense negotiations" with the United States in a bid to strike a new deal on personal data transfers within days.
The European Court of Justice in October ruled that the EU-US "Safe Harbour" arrangement allowing firms to transfer European citizens' personal information to the United States was "invalid" because it did not properly protect the data from spy agencies.
Businesses on both sides of the Atlantic have expressed concerns about the resulting legal limbo, warning of enormous fallout if the two sides fail to reach a new deal by the end of January.
Demonstrators protest against data preservation in front of the US embassy in Berlin on February 1, 2014 Â©Britta Pedersen (DPA/AFP/File)
"Intense negotiations are ongoing as we speak," European Commission spokesman Christian Wigand told a press conference in Brussels on Friday, declining to "speculate" on whether a deal would be reached by January 31.
"We are constructive and available to negotiate... but there will not be an agreement at any price. We need a new arrangement that lives up to the benchmarks that have been set by the European Court of Justice," Wigand said.
Officials in the commission, the executive arm of the 28-nation EU, have said they are aiming to reach a deal around the end of January, without calling it a deadline.
Top European and US trade groups -- Business Europe, Digital Europe, the US Chamber of Commerce and the Information Technology Industry Council -- in mid-January warned the EU and US President Barack Obama of "enormous" fallout for businesses and customers if the two sides fail to strike a deal by January 31.
"We understand there has been some progress in the past couple of days," Paul Meller, spokesman for Digital Europe, told AFP.
"We are cautiously optimistic there will be a deal, if not by Sunday night, then in the coming days after that," he said.
The European data protection authorities are due to meet in Brussels on February 2-3.
The ECJ ruling also alarmed Washington which says it "put at risk the thriving transatlantic digital economy."
The landmark verdict stemmed from a case lodged by Austrian law student Max Schrems, who challenged the Safe Harbour arrangement on the grounds it did not properly protect European data.
